title: (Re-)Constructing “public debates” with CLARIAH MediaSuite tools in print and audiovisual media

author: Berrie van der Molen, Utrecht University

segmentation: The presentation is called reconstructing public debates with Gloria Media Suite tools in print and audiovisual media.
Hopefully it's parenthesis and will become more clear idea there.

In the presentation I will focus on the proceedings of Korea Research pilot debate research across media, or dream by reflecting critically on the implied conceptualization of public debates and on how or leveled research approach can be used to understand such debates.
In the available heterogeneous digital sources.
So I'm one of the authors very familiar, but this was also written by my colleague.
Just myself open Tom Peters.
But the pilot team was actually a little bit bigger show on this slide.
Olivers are included in this research pilot run between two 2017 and 2018 and the purpose was to test and Co developed parts of the Gloria Media Suite.
Now this media suite is a media analysis environment for Dutch academic researchers that rule out automan also presented yesterday, yesterday morning and in this media suite this infrastructure.
Researchers can pick and combine different tools and datasets.

Depending on the research, interest in research questions, so we wanted this pilots and our pilot question was how can public debates on direction regulation between 1945 and 1990 be researched across print and audiovisual datasets.
So this meant that we sought to make possible cross media public debate analysis in this media suite with the implementations in our research pilot.
Now I will show you today a number of these implementations by focusing on how these.
Imply a particular conceptualization of what a public debate is, 'cause we think that's really important to really keep a finger on the pulse of what we're actually doing.
But before we do that.
Or I'll do that.
Let me say a few words about this research interest, because this was really important to this pilot, because all pilots were really built around a concrete, already ongoing research project.
So my personal research on my PhD research is on this interaction between national drug debates and regulation in Ellensburg, 9445 and 1990, and 30.
Broadly speaking, this means that I think about questions about, for instance, do controversies about a particular substance.
Lead to regulation?
Or do you see that regulation of a particular substance actually makes it controversial in the public debate as well?
These kind of questions?
I'm researching and very recently I've been researching in newspapers only.
Not yet in this tool, MDMA or ecstasy, which was very quickly regulated.
How did it affect the public discourse on of this substance?
Just to give you some context about what kind of questions I'm answering my research.

So what we want to do in the media suite and with this research question is to benefit from the access to the large amount of digitized cultural heritage documents from newspaper, television and radio.
And we sort of perceive these as big data.
Yes, so this is you may recognize it.
We were also at the Bazaar yesterday.
This is what the media Suite currently looks like.
So there's, uh, you can.
This is currently the tool for you so you can see you can access it, but it means of the different tools.
You can also go in.
You can also click on data, so then you go in to the different collections and there's a workspace which is the third thing on the top bar where you sort of can do bookmarks and annotations.
So that's where you store all of this and bring it together, and you can sort of go between all of these to sort of make something that really helps you answer your.
Research question.
So in other tools using the newspaper data set of the National Library of the Netherlands, we've come up with the structural method to research historical public debates.
This level approaches, we call, it uses distant reading methods as like signposts to get to actually readable subsets or close reading of actual of actual reading of the material in the.
In this pilot, we wanted to make sure that this approach also works when we simultaneously search the television and radio data is data sets.
Of the Netherlands Institute for Sound and Vision.
How to do public debate analysis across these heterogeneous datasets.

Now our claim here is that insights from media studies can help us as historians to critically bridge the gap between distant and close reading of different digital media sources to reconstruct the public debates.
So I've included a link here and it will also be at the end if you want to read a little bit more about this level.

Approach and this is a schematic overview of it, so very generally speaking is so we start with like this really big datasets and use keyword search and timeline graphs on the on the highest macro level to search that.
Then based on that we get to a sub selection where we look at the word clouds to serious or historical understanding.
Sort of see what these what is like the general meanings or different meanings that are in this sub sets an.
With that we can then make new queries very targeted queries.
Where we get a list of individual results that were done actually in a position to read.
So that's the aim so that we sort of get to actual reading of the material in the end.
But this approach is not like like going just one way.
It's like iterative, so you do this a few times before you get to the material that you really want to.
Analyze.
So enabling this approach across media demanded us to think through what we understand these public debates to be.
As I've said that there's these three different datasets, newspapers, television and radio.
And I'm sorry bout the icon for the radio because my colleague actually Commons it looks more like a face with chopstick in it, but I was too lazy to change it still with, so it's still there.
And the research question about public debates on drugs and regulation is historical, so we need to make sure that the approach gives us material we can actually.
Research with continuous attention 40.
Careful contextualization of events that does justice to all actors involved.
So that's like the historical side.
But we strongly drew on media studies.
Insights to do justice to the different media and analysis methods involved, allowing us to focus on discursive relations in the material.
So now I get to three parts of the implementation of the research pilot and I will reflect on what this means for this conceptualization of public debates.
So on the most basic level, we have to think through what it means to combine prints an audiovisual datasets in an interface with textual distant reading methods.
Of course, that's what they are and print and audiovisual media function entirely differently.
And ideally this should be reflected in the research method as well.
So how how we made a material searchable and also presented on this yesterday is that the newspaper data set came with already very searchable OCR data, so you can search.

In text to search all the material on the word level and currently all the material of the Dallas Institute for submission to the radio and television material is undergoing an automatic speech recognition treatment.
So that will be searchable on the spoken word level as well.
So this sort of brings these two datasets on a level that there's as searchable in this on the same level.
But of course there's a rising issue, and that is that the television and radio datasets are only searchable.
The means of the actually spoken words as well.
So on this analysis level, or maybe I should say on the search level 'cause this is sort of the widest, the highest level.
There is no way to consider the visual discourse at this point.

In the close reading environment, the Media Suite offers an annotation tool that allows the researcher to store timecoded text, and whereas this offers plenty of freedom for any analysis method for the researcher, we haven't figured out yet how this analysis should be done in the context of this level approach, because this potentially yields a very large number, maybe hundreds of results, that all need to be analyzed, so that will be really time consuming, so there's some decisions left to be made there.
Is the.

The annotation tool frozen in action, so you see that this clip is playing out and then at the bottom I've made a segment so you can just make your own segments and their time coded and then with these segments you can you can annotate them using existing thesauri to select X.
Or you can bring in your own text or the story.
Or you can save just written text with these timecode annotations.
So what you see here is that I've I've just added only one text saying drips blood, which means drugs policy, which is again a content tech.
But of course you could do this for anything you could look at framing.
You could do.
You could look at Montana, anything, anything.
So you could on this level on the close reading level it is possible to do justice to the visual discourse as well.
So there are different meaningful points of focus in media studies.

Should a public debate analysis focus on agenda setting points, production history analysis on what there is in the sources, textual analysis or on how they were likely understood by the public back then, which would be something like reception research.

There are many ways to understand and account for the different levels of meaning on this continuum, and we had to be explicit about where on this continuum we look at, meaning an equally importantly which meanings are then excluded from this type of historical narrative.

Well, the media suite does not directly isolate and contextualize historical events, 'cause it's relying on distant reading techniques means that it sort of groups historical sources based on the strategies that have talked about now predefined by the infrastructure.
So it's in that sense sort of artificially bringing that together.
Well, the historical meaning is this red in the digitally compiled source material itself, which precludes a focus on production and reception.
It's just good to have that very clear to make that yeah, to see where we are, actually what we're actually looking at.
The digital compilation of the source material as a public debate is, as I said, more or less artificial.
'cause it does not trace organic connections between the different sources.
This more or less artificial nature of public debates therefore requires an explicit theoretical approach.
'cause what is it we're doing then?
If it's not, if it's not raising this organic collection connection.
So instead of approaching this material as such as organically connected, we focus on discursive relations or strengths in the material.
So one way we do this is by using the word frequency lists that can be visualized as word clouds when we search for a particular drug.
In my case.
So for instance, you see the first part of the query on the screen.
So of both queries is ecstasy or MD, MA or extra workout Y.
So that's the first search query.
You get a number of results.
Hopefully all results are sort of relating to this drug that would.
That would be the name of that.
So, so that will be the most basic query to get all of that, but using the word clouds based on the OC.
On ASR data we can then draw on our historical understanding to recognize and select meaningful related words that are frequently Co occurring.
So here in the first query, in the second part of it you can see that I add the words added the words acid or house or acid house or dense.
So these are all terms that relate to the acid house dense culture, strongly connected to ecstasy.
So bad by then using this combined query so the drug Curry ends this sort of recreation.

One of these words from the recreation recreational strength and I get all results that have something that have some some link there or there are likely to have some link there and that sort of generate this sort of recreational discursive strength of ecstasy.
But of course, that's just one part.

And what we do and what you can do in the media suite by saving these queries with the results in the workspace is stored different types of queries, so the second one is like a criminal query, including police rate, laboratory investigation and this depends on your research question.
In your research interest by by sort of making identifying these different strengths and actually reading them all.
That's why we that's how we get to sort of this idea of public debate analysis by sort of researching all of these trends then and.
Compiling them in historical narrative.

So what I've presented to you is a number of elements of the media suites and the related decisions we've made as part of this research pilot and how the Media Suite accommodates a very particular type of public debate analysis.

This is a conceptual approach to public debates that is not aimed towards like reconstructing, particularly base as they happened, but instead focuses on discursive strengthen process is and it is a result of critical reflection on the research infrastructure.
So what we're actually doing with the material.
So I have proof.

I did a few more reference here that add a little more context to some of the things I've discussed mostly about the level approach, 'cause I realized that it went quite fast and yeah, so if you're interested, you could read more about that, and that's where I want to.
Thank you for your attention.
